item.title: REGRESSION AND RELATIONSHIP IN STATISTICS
item.description: Regression In the original context used by Sir Francis Galton, the term “regress” referred to the statistical phenomenon of regression toward the mean. This means that if a particular trait (such as height) in one generation is unusually extreme (e.g., very tall or very short), the corresponding trait in the next generation tends to be closer to the average or mean value. So, “regress” in this context means to move back or return toward a central or average value.

item.title: Proof of Variance Expression
item.description: Proof of Variance Expression Letâ€™s prove the expression \(s^2 = \frac{1}{n^2} \sum_{i<j}^n (x_i - x_j)^2\) from the given expression \(s^2 = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - \bar{x})^2\). Start with the definition of \(s^2\): \[ s^2 = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i - \bar{x})^2 \] Expand the square: \[ s^2 = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (x_i^2 - 2x_i\bar{x} + \bar{x}^2) \] Simplify the summation: \[ s^2 = \frac{1}{n} \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i^2 - 2\bar{x}\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i + n\bar{x}^2\right) \]
